dt: {bc}to deceive, win over, or induce to do something by artful coaxing and wheedling or shrewd trickery

dt.t: {wi}cozened{/wi} his supper out of the old couple

pt: {sc}cheat{/sc} {sc}cozen{/sc} {sc}defraud{/sc} {sc}swindle{/sc} mean to get something by dishonesty or deception. {sc}cheat{/sc} suggests using trickery that escapes observation.
{sc}cozen{/sc} implies artful persuading or flattering to attain a thing or a purpose.

pt.t: always able to {it}cozen{/it} her grandfather out of a few dollars

pt: {sc}defraud{/sc} stresses depriving one of his or her rights and usually connotes deliberate perversion of the truth.

pt.t: {it}defrauded{/it} of her inheritance by an unscrupulous lawyer

pt: {sc}swindle{/sc} implies large-scale cheating by misrepresentation or abuse of confidence.

pt.t: {it}swindled{/it} of their savings by con artists

et: perhaps from obsolete Italian {it}cozzonare{/it}, from Italian {it}cozzone{/it} horse trader, from Latin {it}cocion-, cocio{/it} trader
shortdef: to deceive, win over, or induce to do something by artful coaxing and wheedling or shrewd trickery
